African-American poetry not even only
these days I mean if you look at the
work I'm going to pick some people
totally off the top of my head you Tracy
K Smith Marilyn Nelson Nikki finny and
Natasha treway let's say um those are
four or African-American uh women poets
and their work you would simply never
mistake the work of one for the other if
you looked at it on the paper you just
you just wouldn't they're talking about
different things they're speaking out of
different um regions in the country
different subject matters different sets
of of concerns um different kinds of

to really emphas emphasize um all that
is quite distinct in African-American
poetry is important so we don't get in
our head that it's it is one thing on
the other hand um is the
African-American musical tradition and
the African-American oral tradition a
tremendous tremendous resource for a

my own work what I'm interested in is
keeping all my ears not just the two of
them you know keeping every ear open to
all there is to to bring into the work
and some of of that listening is
something that any poet can do you know
anybody can listen anybody can you know
uh I I I'm not a jazz musician uh and

African-American but nonetheless an
African-American
tradition it's not any anything that I

something in the same way that a
Shakespearean Sonic because it's great
teaches me something and so you know the

when you think about even in families um
uh that are are in some ways maybe
further away from the really really
richest iterations of an oral tradition
um nonetheless I think that um for

think of as a Poetics um and that that
is something that that that maybe that's

saying
um but again whether or not we choose to
draw on it depends on the

that poetries had on hip-hop just as far
as you know putting things in historical
order um and that you know when hip hop
emerged in in the late 1970s and early
1980s um it was coming out of many
traditions and many sets of
circumstances but um the oral tradition
of toasting right of toasting and
boasting and roasting
that's a part of the black tradition
that sort of getting up and playing the
dozens you know all of those competitive
uh verbal Traditions are totally
especially in early hip-hop just all

that's a poetic resource certainly the

that you know in sampling there are a
million uh references the

when it's not necess necessarily

something that feels like literary

people probably a little bit younger

really came up in the hip-hop era I mean

other things but that hip hop was always
